cab.content: SES0H/E11. "T" MINISTRY OP FOOD.-A K^^eport for Week ending Wednesday, March 5, 1919. PART' I.-ACTION TAKEN. Sir John Beale has resigned his seat on the Food Council. Mr. H. F. Paul andSir John Miller, Assistant Secretaries in charge of the Cereals and Local AuthoritiesDivisions respectively, have been appointed additional members of the Council. A Departmental Committee has been appointed to investigate the incidence and administration of the bread subsidy. The members are Mr. McCurdy (Chairman),Mr. Paul, Mr. Baines, Sir Lionel Halsey, and the Legal Adviser. Mr. McCallum will act as Secretary. The following particulars as to the numbers and cost of the staff of the Ministryof Food at the date of the Armistice and on. February 26th last respectively, have beengiven in answer to a question in the House of Commons : - , llth November 1918. 26th February 1919. Number. Cost. Number. Cost.Headquarter Staff - - - -Provincial Staff- '- - - -Total - '- - 4,700 4,100 070,000 560.000 3,700 3,100 580,000 440,000 8,800. 1,230,000 6,800 r - 1,020,000 Inter-Departmental Committee on the Reduction of Food Prices, -The Committeemet on March 4th. The question of a further reduction in the price of imported meat was againdiscussed, and it was proposed that the price should be reduced either by 3d. per lb.. on May 1st and Id. per lb. on July 1st, or by 2d. per lb. on May 1st and 2d.per lb. on July 1st. No definite decision was, however, reached owing to the repre-sentatives of H.M. Treasury being unwilling at the present stage to undertake liability for certain charges put forward by the Ministry of Food in order to effect these reductions. Food Council. Meetings of the Council were held on February 28th and march 4th. ; Reductions in the prices of certain cereals (maize, peas, beans, &c.) were approved ;the reductions in the wholesale prices will be made from March 17th, and in the retail prices from April 1st. . . Upon the question of supply and distribution of cheese, it was decided- " (1) that the supplies in sight warranted the abolition of the present system of distribution. (2) that application should be made to H.M. Treasury for sanction to the purchase of the exportable surplus of Canadian cheese, in addition to the Australian cheese coming forward; and that all possible steps should be taken to obtain this amount at less than 23 cents per lb., the price at present offered. The potato situation was also considered by the Council. It was agreed that, inview of the various representations now being made, a memorandum stating the exact position of the Ministry in regard to payment of compensation should be forwarded to the Cabinet for their information. As regards export, it was reportedthat it was doubtful whether the French Government could take delivery of any large amount over and above the present contract for 200,000 tons owing tocongestion of ports ; but that it was expected that sanction would be given by theChancellor of the Exchequer for the sale of potatoes to Germany and it was proposedthat strong pressure should then be placed upon the Shipping Controller to providetonnage. A (33)7576-1 Pk9 150 3/19 E&S A The question of reducing the manufacturing costs and the price of margarine wasconsidered in relation to the necessity for maintaining a satisfactory quality. It wasdecided (1) to abolish, statutory specifications, while requiring all proposed specifications and prices to be submitted and retaining power to disapprove of any proposals. (2) to sell oils at the following prices: Palm kernel,. 63Z. per ton. Coconut, 64L 10s. per ton." * Ground nut, 65L per ton. American cotton oil, 951. per ton. (3) to retain maximum retail prices. The question of the continuance of Clause 1 of the Bread Order, 1918, according to which bread must not be sold until 12 hours after it has been made, was referred to the Consumers' Council for consideration in the first instance. This clause is no longer required for the purposes of the Ministry of Food, but is being maintained at the request of the Ministry of Labour. Consumers' Council. The Council met on March 5th. The following were the principal resolutions passed : (1) The Council having had under consideration the conditions now prevailing in Eastern and South-Eastern and Central Europe, are of the opinion that unless speedy help is forthcoming, millions of men, women and children now inhabiting these countries will be overwhelmed with famine, and .' that the economic ruin of the countries concerned will be complete. They believe that the danger is imminent, and that the misery and suffering of the people has reached such a height as to move all humane men and women to pity and dismay, and that the disastrous consequences to be expected would involve not only these unhappy nations but the whole of civilisation. They therefore urge that the Associated Governments shall deal without delay with the question of relief, and arrange for the immediate despatch and dis- tribution of food and for the means of reinstating transport, and thus remove the most serious menace now threatening the peace of the world. (2) The Council draws attention to the unfortunate result of premature removal of control, and views with apprehension the organised attempt to bring about a general withdrawal of Food Control. The Council believes that if this attempt is successful, although a temporary reduction of some articles of food may be effected by artificial means, the result in face of the world's situation will be further profiteering at the expense of the. consumer. The Council urges upon the Food Controller and the Government the necessity of continuing these methods of control which have been so successful during the war in keeping down profiteering and equalising distribution until such times as, in view of all circumstances, release can safely be effected. SUPPLIES AND DISTRIBUTION.I Meat. At the special Labour Conference held on March 1st, the financial arrange- ments of the Meat Section were explained in detail, it being explained how the flat rate at which meat is sold had been fixed in such a way that the losses on purchases in North America were balanced by profits on purchases made elsewhere. The Conference expressed its satisfaction with the way in which the Ministry had dealt with the problem. The Meat Trade Advisory Committee, which was appointed for the purpose of advising the Ministry on technical questions involved in the de-control of meat supplies, has approved the outline of a scheme of de-control prepared by the Meat Section, and has agreed to certain orders prescribing the. maximum prices to be paid by importers for frozen meat and authorising the Food Controller to requisition all such meat on arrival. The object of these orders would be to enable the Food Controller to control any free shipment of meat which may arrive before the control of distribution ceases. Bacon, Rams and Lard. Purchases have been completed in the United States for 25,000 tons, and in Canada for 10,000 tons. The adequacy of wholesalers' stocks throughout the country is being kept under observation by means of fortnightlyreturns. Fish. There has been, an increase in the supplies of fish in the Northern Division.In the North-Eastern Division supplies have been uncertain and prices have fluctuatedaccordingly. , Seventy trawlers are awaiting repair, the work being held up by thestrike of the boilermakers and shipwrights. In the' North-Western Division thesupplies of fish have greatly increased ; in this Division 8 out of 35 released trawlershave been refitted and used for fishing, and 11 Dutch boats have also been madeavailable. * In the North Midland Division supplies at the port of Grimsby have been well maintained. In this connection it.is to be noted that &t a meeting of Grimsbytrawler owners it was agreed that, notwithstanding the withdrawal of control, catchesshould not be sold at prices exceeding those in the control schedule recently in force.' In the North and West of Scotland catches of herrings and white fish have beenpoor, but the prices have been below the maximum owing to the arrival of largequantities of Norwegian herrings. The removal of control is viewed wdth some apprehension by several of theCommissioners as likely to lead to a rise in price in spite of the considerable increasein supplies. Milk. Supplies of milk are rapidly increasing in most parts of the country, andthe chief difficulty in the immediate future will be the proper disposal of the surplusproduced by the abnormally early spring flush. The general demand will beincreased by the immediate withdrawal of the Milk (Restriction in Establishments)Order, the Ice Cream (Restriction) Order, and Clause 1 of the Use of Milk(Licensing) Order, which restricts the use of milk in the manufacture of chocolate,confectionery, &c. Steps have been taken to ensure a continuance of milk supplies in urban districts in the event of a transport strike. The Ministry are pressing' on orders, for 10,000 standard 10-gallon churnsfrom Woolwich and 8,500 from private manufacturers in order to remedy the presentshortage of churns. The Travelling Commission appointed to inquire into the cost of - milk production has made the following interim recommendation to the Food Controller : " This Commission, which is how considering the cost of production of milk, recommends that maximum prices should be fixed for milk both for , summer 1919 and winter 1919-20, and is of opinion that it is essential, in order to obtain supplies, that the maximum prices fixed should be such as to afford a reasonable profit; and further recommends that an immediate announcement on these lines should be made by the Food Controller." This recommendation is being considered in conjunction with the general problem of the future of milk control. Potatoes. A deputation of potato growers, including representatives of theParliamentary Agricultural Committee of the House of Commons, was. received by thePresident of the Board of Agriculture and the Food Controller on February 28th. whenthe liabilities of the Government in regard to the 1918 potato crop were discussed. Jam. Ample supplies of orange marmalade are available in all parts of thecountry. There, are very few complaints in regard to the shortage of jam andthe Ministry has only been asked to supply 25 tons weekly during the past month to meet shortages. Attention has been drawn to contracts which have been and are being made between jam manufacturers, fruit dealers, and fruit growers for various kinds of fruitto be delivered during the coming season at prices greatly in excess of those obtaininglast season. The Food Controller has intimated that, should evidence continue to accumulate that fruit prices are likely to reach unreasonable limits during the approaching season through speculation at this juncture, he will consider it his duty to re-impose the control exercised during the past two seasons. Jam manufacturers have also been reminded that the Orders controlling jamprices are still in force and will not be revoked until it is certain that the prices ofjams and marmalade will as a result of supply and demand fall below the presentmaximum prices, and that should there be a fruit crop of average size during thecoming season any revision of jam prices will be in the nature of a reduction. Tea. Arrangements have now been made with the distributing trade for the transition from control to freedom of distribution and prices, 4 - A ballot was held on March 3rd, and a further ballot will be held on March 24th.Licensed wholesalers will receive their ordinary rebates on all National Control Teawhich was balloted before March 3rd. Up to March 24th these teas may be sold only under National Control conditions but after that date they may be sold at varyingprices. Licensees under the ballot who have received supplies of tea in excess of theirapplications will receive a rebate of 3d. per lb. on the stocks of such teas in their possession on.March 24th in order that these excess quantities may be put on thesame basis as tea balloted under the new conditions. No other rebates will be paid and no compensation will be given to wholesalers or retailers in respect of any stocksheld on March 24th. . ., Dried Fruits. 6,000 tons of currants and 5,000 tons of Persian dates havearrived during the week, and are being put into distribution forthwith. since february 17th approximately 20,000 tons of various dried fruits have beeu distributed to the trade. Cocoa. Large quantities of raw cocoa have been distributed to the manufacturers.The total amount distributed since January 1st, 1919 is 20,000 tons, and manu-facturers now hold considerable stocks. Shipments and arrivals continue to be satisfactory., ORDERS UNDER DEFENCE OF THE REALM REGULATIONS. A notice dated 27th February 1919, revokes the Barley (Restriction) Order, 1917,and the Cereals (Restriction) Orders, 1918, as from the 1st March. The restrictions onthe use of barley, except for the manufacture of malt, are thereby removed. A notice dated 7th February 1919, revokes as from the 1st March the Sugar(Brewers' Restriction) Orders, 1917 and 1918. A licence is no longer necessary toenable brewers to obtain low grade sugai^, nor are there now any restrictions as to thequantity of such sugar which brewers may use. The Edible Oils (Maximum Prices) Order, 1919, dated 28th February 1919, fixesmaximum prices for cotton seed oil and various other oils. Hitherto no maximum pricehas been fixed for these oils in small quantities, as practically all were distributed inthe manufacture of compound. It is now possible to release them for retail trade. An Order dated the 28th February 1919 amending the Intoxicating Liquor (output and Delivery Order, 1917, permits an increase of 50 per cent, in the amount of spiritsallowed to be delivered under the principal Order.6! An Order amending the Meat (Maximum Prices) Order, 1917, dated 1st March1919, reduces the wholesale price of beef, mutton, lamb and veal as from 3rdMarch. The retail prices also are reduced by 2d. per lb. ENFORCEMENT OF ORDERS. The total number of prosecutions during the week ended February 22nd was 785,of which 702 resulted in convictions. Prosecutions were reported under 68 differentOrders. At Woolwich a firm was fined 100Z. and 51. 5s. costs for selling cheese above themaximum price. At Tamworth a wine and spirit merchant was charged 246L in fines and costs forselling whisky at 12s. Qd. a bottle, instead of at the maximum price of 9s. PART IL-SUMMARY OF THE FOOD POSITION. IMPORTS. Though the total imports of the principal foods and feeding-stuffs in the weekended March 1st (118,200) tons increased somewhat on those of the two precedingweeks they were still below the average of the first nine weeks of the calendar year(161,500 tons) or of the first 26 weeks of the cereal year (174,200 tons). Wheat and flour imports (29,000 tons as equivalent grain) were again low, as also were barley(2,500 tons), oats (600 tons), rice (none), and sugar (8,000 tons). Apart from these articles, imports showed an all-round improvement, especially maize (22,600 tons),meat (18,800 tons), bacon (15,400 tons), lard (3,000 tons), cheese (2,800 tons), condensed Total Imports for the first 26 weeks of Cereal Year (1st September to 1st March). 1918-1!). Sugar -Tea -Coffee -Cocoa - Tons. 271,500 63,900 30,400 44,100 66,300 504,000 103,900 8,000 54,100 Tons. 4- 148,100 4- 55,900 4- 10,600 - 27,100 - 19,700 4- 13,700 Per Cent. 4-- 120 4- 695 4- 54 - 100 - 31 4- 26 2,446,500 + 892,300 4- 57 60,600 633,600 317,500 - 165,200 - 172,400 4- 7,300 - 73 - 21 4- 2 - 179,200 - 26 4- 22,600 ! 4- 28 4- 3,800 1 4- 92 4- 43,100 4- 391 1 CONSUMPTION. Flour. The rapid increase in the quantity of flour delivered from the mills orreleased from imported supplies during the present year shows signs of easing off, theincrease for civilian consumption in the last period quoted in Table B (1) beingcounterbalanced by the reduction in estimated army requirements. It may be observed that the total increase of supplies in the first eight weeks of the year overthe normal rate of consumption of the latter part of last year amounts to about one week's supply. While this increase is no doubt due in part to the permission givento consumers to hold private- stocks, the bulk of the additional supplies has passed into local trade stocks which have been built up under the Ministry as a protection against possible temporary dislocation of the means of transport. Butchers Meat. In the third week of February there was a* tendency for home supplies in Great Britain to fall off in anticipation of the further rise of prices to farmers on 1st March. This movement within the month is illustrated in the following-table, which shows the numbers of fat cattle and sheep recorded as stalled in GreatBritain, also the corresponding variations in the issues of imported meat: Week ended Cattle Stalled. Sheep Stalled. Issue of Imported "Meat.January 11th t January 18th January 25th -February 1st - - -February 8th - - - -February 15th - - - -February 22nd - . No. 36,600 34,100 26,500 17,200 38,600 31,800 27,300 No. 105,800 86,300 70,400 46,600 89,600 78,400 63,400 Tons. 7,520 7,500 8,660 10,680 8,140 8,420 7,260A 7576- 1 Bmilk (3,300 tons), and tea (7,300 tons). Fruit imports were somewhat less thanthose pi the preceding week, though there was a good supply of apples (7,900 tons). In the following table are given the total imports of the principal foods for thefirst half of the cereal year 1918-19, together with the increases and decreases onthe first half of 1917-18. The most noteworthy feature in the comparison is thelarge.increase in imports of wheat combined with decreases in flour and cereals otherthan wheat. The. change in the percentage of dilution required in the regulationflour, culminating in the restoration of the white loaf, .and the increase in the eon-sumption of flour (indicated in Table B (1)) have been factors affecting the position.The imports of meat are not materially greater than in the first half of the preceding year, but the large increases in bacon and lard, as well as in condensed milk, clearlyshow the effect of the Ministry's purchases in America, while the disappearance of margarine as an import marks the substitution of British for the foreign-made product.As regards sugar it will be seen that the decrease in imports was very considerable and it was necessary to conserve stocks until hostilities were suspended. The tablealso shows a relatively large decrease in cheese imports and increases in butter, tea,coffee and cocoa. These figures do not represent total home supplies, which apart from thefluctuations within the month are coming forward well up to anticipations. In thefour weeks ended 22nd February average weekly supplies of home-grown meat inGreat Britain are estimated at 14,600 tons, while the distribution of imported meataveraged 8,600 tons. A year ago the corresponding quantities were 13,600 tons ofhome meat and 5,900 tons of imported meat. Estimated total consumption of rationedmeats continued below the ration quantity, that for the four weeks ended 22ndFebruary being 5 per cent, below the quantity to which the public are entitled on thecoupons phis the additional allowances now made to butchers and caterers. Fish. Supplies of fish both at Billingsgate and in the principal inland marketsduring the first three weeks of February "showed a great improvement on those for january. The figures week by week are given in the following table : Supplies of Fish at large Inland Markets.- Jan. 4th, Jan.11th. Jan. 18th. Jan. 25th, Feb. 1st. During the week ended Febuary 22nd, stocks of meat and provisions were againgenerally reduced, the principal reductions being meat 2,400 tons, bacon 800 tons,canned meat 1,100 tons, canned fish 500 tons, cheese 3,] 00 tons, imtter 600 tons,condensed milk 1,100 tons, and sugar 11,000 tons. D.--rSioOris of the PRINCIPAL FOODS and FEEDING STUFFS in the UNITED KINGDOM. The figures foi wheat and flour include stocks iu port granaries and warehouses, inland warehouses,mills, and bakers' shops, as well as estimated stocks on farms ; those for barley, oats, beans, and peasinclude stocks in port granaries and warehouses and iu mills, in maltsters' hands, and estimated farm stocks ;those for maize, rice, and grain meals include stocks in port granaries and warehouses and in mills. The figures for sugar are stocks in possession of the Sugar Commission ;. those for butter, margarine,lard, cheese, condensed milk, meat, and fish include stocks at ports, in cold stores, aud in importers'andwholesalers' warehouses. The figures for tea, coffee, aud cocoa are stocks remaining in bonded warehouses or entered to bewarehoused ; and those for oilseeds and oilseed cake include stocks at ports and in the hands of millers,crushers, and cake manufacturers.Article,February 1st, 1919.January 1st, 1919.February 1st, 1918.Slocks in the United Kingdom including estimated Farm Stocks.Wheat (including flour)BarleyOatsBeans -
